title: About
text:
Professional experience
Research on the Relationship between Fish Weight and Fish Length | October 202-December 2021 * Cleaned 5,000+ raw data; processed data in R and found variables of weight and length were highly skewed. * Detected the relationship between two variables; applied log transformation to linearize the relationship, resulting in an 26.7% increase in accuracy. * Performed residual scatterplot and residual histogram to ensure the normal distribution; accurately modeling the relationship between fish weight and fish length.
Henry & Stark County Health Department | June 2022-August 2022
* Researched, synthesized, and compiled environmental health policies and procedures enforced by Henry & Stark County to generate a single and organized document with more than 200 pages for staff training, effectively reduced the average time spent in file research time by 95%. * Designed a user-friendly dashboard template that tracks health inspection data and automatically renews charts with visualized data (histograms, line plot, pie chart), which is actively used by relevant staff members. * Developed a 20-page professional Foodborne Illness Risk Factor Report under the guidance of FDA Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards.

title: About
text:
Academic interest
Take lead roles in designing new statistical and computational methodologies to analyze environmental and biomedical data and solve health problems. Bring innovative ideas from statistical research to people’s lives to bridge the gap between academic findings and practical public health and promote health equities around the world

title: Jiaxin(Jessi) Huang
text: Hi everyone! I’m Jessi. I graduated from the University of Washington with a Bachelor degree in Environmental health. I’m a first year master student in Biostatistics program at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. I enjoy cooking, traveling and outdoor activities like hiking and skiing. Here is a photo of me at undergraduate graduation ceremony.
